metadata.title: Construct Design | CDK for Terraform
metadata.description: Write highly configurable construct classes that provide guidance for a wide range of use cases.

mdxSource.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={};const MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components,...props}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...props,components:components,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Custom construct classes are reusable infrastructure configurations written in a programming language.`),mdx("p",null,`Similar to `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/language/modules"},`Terraform modules`),`, constructs let you reuse configurations, enforce infrastructure best practices, and abstract configuration details away from users. For example, you might create a construct that configures a Kubernetes deployment.`),mdx("p",null,`Constructs can also use programming functionality to provide more customization and guidance than a Terraform module. Users only customize modules through inputs, so complex modules can expose hundreds of options. Even if the module provides valid defaults, users must determine which inputs are relevant to their use case and how to configure them. Constructs are much more flexible. For example, a construct can dynamically build defaults from non-input values and let users override methods that create infrastructure objects.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"choosing-a-language"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#choosing-a-language","aria-label":"choosing a language permalink"},`\xbb`),`Choosing a Language`),mdx("p",null,`You can write a custom construct in any language CDKTF supports.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"creating-constructs-for-a-single-language"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#creating-constructs-for-a-single-language","aria-label":"creating constructs for a single language permalink"},`\xbb`),`Creating Constructs for a Single Language`),mdx("p",null,`You can write `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`Construct`),` classes and store them locally, either within your CDKTF application or in a separate, shared directory. We recommend storing constructs in a separate directory when you have multiple CDKTF applications in a monorepo setup.`),mdx("p",null,`When you write constructs in the same language as your CDKTF application, you can use the same importing mechanisms you use with other applications. Refer to `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/concepts/constructs"},`Constructs`),` in the CDKTF Concepts documentation for more details about using constructs.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"creating-constructs-for-multiple-languages"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#creating-constructs-for-multiple-languages","aria-label":"creating constructs for multiple languages permalink"},`\xbb`),`Creating Constructs for Multiple Languages`),mdx("p",null,`You have two options for writing constructs for users to consume in multiple programming languages.`),mdx("p",null,`The first option is writing your construct in Typescript and using `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"https://aws.github.io/jsii/"},mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"a"},`jsii`)),` to translate it to other languages. This approach requires some setup and configuration. Refer to the `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"https://aws.github.io/jsii/user-guides/lib-author/quick-start/set-up/"},`JSII getting started guide`),` for details. You can also use the `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`cdktf-construct`),` projen template to get started more quickly. Refer to `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/develop-custom-constructs/publishing-and-distribution#publish-constructs-with-projen"},`Publish Constructs with Projen`),` for details.`),mdx("p",null,`The second option is using Terraform Modules as an intermediate layer. You can use the `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"https://github.com/cdktf/cdktf-tf-module-stack"},`cdktf-tf-module-stack`),` to transform your code into a Terraform module, import the module into any CDKTF application, and let CDKTF `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/concepts/modules#add-module-to-cdktf-json"},`generate the local code bindings`),` required to use it. This approach lets you write your construct in any language and requires less setup than using `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`jsii`),`. However, you are limited to the structure and functionality available in a Terraform module. For example, you cannot use programming functionality like enums or methods to provide advanced configuration options.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"design-best-practices"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#design-best-practices","aria-label":"design best practices permalink"},`\xbb`),`Design Best Practices`),mdx("p",null,`Use the following best practices to guide construct development.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"make-your-construct-highly-configurable"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#make-your-construct-highly-configurable","aria-label":"make your construct highly configurable permalink"},`\xbb`),`Make Your Construct Highly Configurable`),mdx("p",null,`Let users overwrite attributes when possible. This prevents users from having to overwrite or modify your construct’s outputs if they need to change your defaults.`),mdx("p",null,`You can also consider organizing logic into methods that users can overwrite through inheritance. This approach is similar to the template method pattern popular in Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) languages. For example, you might create methods for tasks like getting a secret from a source or accessing all available regions.`),mdx("p",null,`The following example shows how template methods can let users customize which secrets their application retrieves for a docker container.`),mdx("pre",{"className":"language-typescript"},mdx("code",{parentName:"pre","className":"language-typescript"},mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`class`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token class-name"},mdx("span",{parentName:"span","className":"token maybe-class-name"},`LocalDockerDeployment`)),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`extends`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token class-name"},mdx("span",{parentName:"span","className":"token maybe-class-name"},`Construct`)),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`{`),`
